Chapter 24, Part 2: Karma
Good sons!
There are two kinds of offenses committed by sentient beings:
First, those with evil precepts; second, those without precepts.
Even if a person with evil precepts kills one sheep, or does not kill, they always incur the sin of killing.
Why is it so?
Because they have made a vow beforehand.
Even if a person without precepts kills a thousand people, they incur the sin of killing when they kill, but not when they do not kill.
Why is it so?
Because they have not made a vow.
Therefore, all good and evil dharmas have the mind as their root.
Because of the root, it is said that bhiká¹£us commit offenses in two ways:
First, offenses committed by the body; second, offenses committed by speech; there are no offenses committed without the mind.
Such precepts, if incomplete in time or incomplete in parts, cannot be received.
It is like drilling for fire - if there is a drill, strength, and dry tinder, then fire can be obtained. If any one of these is lacking, then fire cannot be obtained. The precepts are also like this.
Such precepts, whether obtained, abandoned, upheld, or violated, all depend on the mind;
The TathÄgata clearly knows the nature of all dharmas, and therefore establishes them.
If there are people who, due to the power of contemplating good karma, do not create evil, this is called the precepts in accordance with the Dharma;
If obtained from others, it is called receiving the precepts.
If there were merit in being apart from receiving the precepts, then all evil beasts - lions, tigers, and wolves - should obtain merit, but in fact they do not.
For this reason, those who receive good precepts obtain immeasurable blessings, and those who receive evil precepts obtain immeasurable offenses.
Therefore, the sÅ«tras speak of evil observances - first, raising sheep, second, raising
The third is raising pigs, the fourth is fishing, the fifth is netting fish,
the sixth is killing cows, the seventh is a jailer, the eighth is raising hunting dogs,
the ninth is making long snares, the tenth is becoming a hunter, the eleventh is casting spells on dragons, the twelfth is killing
people, the thirteenth is becoming a thief, the fourteenth is being a gossip, the fifteenth is using painful whips,
chains, shackles, and burning irons on people - kings,
ministers who deceive those who entrust them and do not know gratitude, those with a bad temper and an evil mind, the chief of a large and evil village,
those who collect taxes and confiscate goods, and monks who violate the precepts and have no sense of shame - such people all have no precepts;
even though they are not called those who engage in unwholesome actions, they still incur great offenses.
Why is it so?
Because they do it for their whole lives.
If one does not make a vow or accept it from others for such things, then it is not accomplished.
Thus, these evil precepts are abandoned in four situations:
First, when one obtains the two organs; second, when one gives up one's life; third, when one receives wholesome precepts; fourth, when one severs the bonds of desire.
Some say that just as wholesome precepts are complete, so are evil precepts. This is not so!
Why is it so?
Because evil precepts are easily obtained, and are obtained through a single cause, namely, making a vow.
Wholesome precepts are not like this. There are five skillful means, namely the five roots. Therefore, they are difficult to obtain;
Because they are difficult to obtain, they must be complete.

If someone says that the precepts of an upÄsaka do not include meaningless speech or divisive speech, and therefore the precepts of an upÄsaka, the eight precepts of the poá¹£adha, and the novice monk and fully ordained monk precepts are not fully obtained, this is not so!
Why is it so?
Because I now uphold the pure practice of speech.
If someone says, 'I uphold the five precepts, purifying body, speech, and mind,' but their mind is impure, know that such a person does not obtain the complete precepts.
It is like a person who has taken up evil precepts. Even if they do not kill, they always have evil precepts accomplished.
A bhiká¹£u who violates the precepts is also like this.
Why is it so?
Because after receiving the precepts, on each precept there are many karmas and many fruits.
Because sentient beings are immeasurable, the precepts are also immeasurable;
Because objects are immeasurable, the precepts are also immeasurable.
These good and evil precepts are all of three kinds, namely superior, middling, and inferior.
If one does not accept evil precepts, even if one commits many offenses, it is not called evil precepts.
If there is an objection,
'Why are the five precepts to be upheld for one's whole life, while the eight precepts of the fasting practice are to be observed for one day and one night?'
One should say,
'The TathÄgata well knows the characteristics of dharmas and has unobstructed penetration, thus he speaks like this.
Good sons!
There are two kinds of fields of blessings in the world:
First, the field of merit, and second, the field of repaying kindness.
To destroy these two fields is called the five heinous crimes.
These five heinous crimes have three causes and conditions:
First, having an extremely evil mind, second, not recognizing blessings and virtues, and third, not seeing the true fruits.
If a person kills an arhat with a different thought, they do not commit a heinous crime, and the same is true for parents.

If one has no sense of shame, does not consider repaying kindness, and has no respect in their heart, but only makes preparations and does not commit the fundamental act, although it is not a heinous crime, one will still receive a great retribution.

Because of good instruction, because of affection, because of being able to endure, because of doing what is difficult to do, and because of enduring great suffering, therefore parents are called the field of repaying kindness.
If someone kills their parents and then cultivates goodness, although this goodness is cultivated, it will not bring any reward.
Therefore, I say that when people are shaded by it, even for a short time, they should be careful not to break off its branches, flowers, or leaves.
Good sons!
After my nirvana, there will be disciples who will say, 'If one kills one's parents with a different thought and a different name, one does not commit a heinous crime,' which is the Dharmaguptaka.
Some will say, 'Although one kills one's parents with a different thought, one still commits a heinous crime,' which is the MahÄ«Å›Äsaka.
Some will say, 'Killing one's parents with a different thought and a different name, one commits a heinous crime,' which is the SarvÃ¢stivÄda.
Why is it so?
Because the truth of the world is trustworthy, and the truth of one's parents' thoughts also does not change. If one kills them with an evil mind, one commits a heinous crime.
If one truly has parents but does not think of them as parents, and does not give rise to an evil mind, even if one's parents die, one does not commit a heinous crime.
Why is it so?
One commits a heinous crime only when four things are complete:
First,

First, regarding one's parents, one has the thought of them as one's parents; second, one has an evil mind; third, one has a mind to abandon them; fourth, one has the thought of them as sentient beings.
If one possesses these four things, the offense of going against [one's parents] is accomplished;
if one does not possess them, it is not accomplished.

If one gives them the means to die out of pity, respect, to receive the Dharma, out of fear, or for the sake of fame, although one does not kill with one's own hands, one still commits the offense of going against [one's parents].
If one kills one's parents at the behest of another, crying and grieving while doing it, the characteristics of such an offense are light at the beginning, middle, and end.
If one wishes to kill one's parents but mistakenly kills another person instead, one does not commit the offense of going against [one's parents];
if one wishes to kill another person but mistakenly kills one's parents instead, it is the same.
If one wishes to kill one's mother but mistakenly kills someone similar to her, hides the knife, and then strikes one's mother again, one does not commit the offense of going against [one's parents].
The mother has a different view, the child has a different killing, only the killing crime is obtained, not the crime of going against.

These five heinous crimes, killing one's father is light, killing one's mother is heavy, killing an arhat is heavier than killing one's mother, drawing blood from a Buddha is heavier than killing an arhat, and destroying the Saá¹…gha is heavier than drawing blood from a Buddha.

There are things that are heavy but the mind is light, there are things that are light but the mind is heavy, there are things that are heavy and the mind is heavy, there are things that are light and the mind is light.
Things are heavy but the mind is light, such as killing one's parents without an evil mind;
Things are light but the mind is heavy, such as killing an animal with an evil mind;
Things are heavy and the mind is heavy, such as killing one's mother with an extremely evil mind;
Things are light and the mind is light, such as lightly killing an animal.

Thus, evil karma has heavy preparatory actions, but the fundamental and completed [actions] are light;ğŸ”½There are those with light preparatory actions and fundamental [actions], but the completed [action] is heavy;
There are those with heavy preparatory actions and fundamental [actions], but the completed [action] is light;
Some are light in the fundamental but heavy in the expedient and completion.
The objects are of one kind, but due to the power of the mind, one obtains light or heavy fruits.
Good sons!
If someone wants to give food to me, but before giving it to me, they give it to a starving dog, I also praise such a person as a great donor.
Whether it is a field of blessings or not, if one gives without discrimination, one will obtain immeasurable blessings.
Why is this?
Because the mind is pure.
This karma is of four kinds:
First, retribution in the present life; second, retribution in the next life; third, retribution in a later life; fourth, no retribution.
Karma is of four kinds:

First, the time is definite but the retribution is indefinite; second, the retribution is definite but the time is not necessarily definite; third, both the time and the retribution are definite; fourth, neither the time nor the retribution is definite.
Time refers to the present, the next life, and the life after that.
If the time is indefinite, the retribution is indefinite, and this karma can be transformed.
If the retribution is certain to be experienced in the future, this karma can be transformed to be experienced in the present.
Why is it so?
Because of the power of the wholesome mind and wisdom, even certain evil fruits can be transformed to be lighter.
For what reasons is it called certain retribution?
Because it is done constantly without regret, done with single-minded focus, done with joy and delight, made with a vow, and done with joy, therefore this karma attains certain retribution.
Except for this, all are called indefinite.
Sentient beings' karmic actions have heaviness and lightness, distance and nearness. According to their causes and conditions, they will experience them sooner or later.

There are those who cultivate the body, cultivate precepts, cultivate the mind, and cultivate wisdom, and definitely know that good and evil will have consequences. Such people can transform heavy karma into light, and the light will not be experienced.

If one encounters a field of merit and a good spiritual friend, cultivates the path and cultivates goodness, this person can transform heavy offenses from future lives into light experiences in the present life.
If a person has all the karma of the desire realm, attaining the fruit of anÄgÄmin can transform future karma into present experience;
The fruit of arhatship is also like this.
Good man!

If the wise are able to cultivate the body, cultivate precepts, cultivate the mind, and cultivate wisdom, this person can destroy extremely heavy karma, like an agada spell or a poison-removing jewel destroying evil poisons.
If one commits a small offense, the initial expedient is light, but later it becomes heavy. This person does not cultivate the body, precepts, mind, or wisdom, causing the light to become heavy.
If sentient beings create one kind, two kinds, up to various kinds, some are incomplete, some are complete.
First thinking and then acting is called complete action;
Not giving rise to thought first but directly acting is called incomplete action.
There are those who have committed offenses but have not fully completed them, meaning those who have committed offenses but whose karmic retribution is uncertain;
there are those who have committed offenses and have also fully completed them, meaning those who have committed offenses and will definitely receive retribution.
There are those who have committed offenses but have not fully completed them, meaning the retribution is certain but the timing is uncertain;

there are those who have committed offenses and have also fully completed them, meaning both the timing and retribution are certain.ğŸ”½There are those who have committed offenses but have not fully completed them, meaning those who uphold precepts and have right views;

there are those who have committed offenses and have also fully completed them, meaning those who violate precepts and have wrong views.ğŸ”½There are those who have committed offenses but have not fully completed them, meaning those who believe in causes and effects;
there are those who have committed offenses and have also fully completed them, meaning those who do not believe in causes and effects.
There are those who have committed offenses but have not fully completed them, meaning those who commit evil deeds but are surrounded by good;
there are those who have committed offenses and have also fully completed them, meaning those who commit evil deeds and are surrounded by evil.
There are those who have committed offenses but have not fully completed them, meaning those who commit many evil deeds but receive retribution in the human realm;

There are those who have committed and fully completed [evil deeds], who commit evil in the human realm and receive retribution in hell.ğŸ”½There are those who have committed but not fully completed [evil deeds], who have a mind of right mindfulness;
there are those who have committed and fully completed [evil deeds], who have no mindful mind.
There are those who have committed but not fully completed [evil deeds], who regret it at the three times;
there are those who have committed and fully completed [evil deeds], who do not regret it at the three times.
As with evil, so it is with goodness.
Because of this, having committed and fully completed [evil deeds], one may do little and receive much, or do much and receive little.
One thought molds the body, and once the body is formed, there are countless thoughts that mold the body. The initial thought is goodness.
Once the body is formed, one obtains two kinds of fruits:
mixed goodness and evil.
As with humans, so it is with gods.
Hell beings mold their bodies with evil thoughts, and once the body is formed, it is entirely evil.
Hungry ghosts and animals also touch the body with evil intentions, and once the body is formed, it is a mixture of good and bad.
The intermediate existence of good and evil touches the body with good and evil, and once the body is formed, it receives mixed retributions, both good and bad.
Even at the stage of kalala and up to old age, it also receives mixed retributions, both good and bad.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra speaks of four kinds of karma:
Black karma with black retribution, white karma with white retribution, mixed karma with mixed retribution, and neither black nor white karma with no retribution.
Black karma with black retribution refers to the hells;
White karma with white retribution refers to the form heavens;
Mixed karma with mixed retribution refers to the desire heavens, humans, animals, and hungry ghosts;
Neither white nor black karma with no retribution refers to the uncontaminated [karma].
Good sons!
If a person does not understand such karmic causes and conditions, they will transmigrate in birth and death for immeasurable eons.
Why is it so?

Those who do not understand such karmic causes and conditions, even if they are born in the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception with a lifespan of 80,000 eons, will still fall back into the three evil paths when their blessings are exhausted.
Good son!
All models and drawings are not superior to the mind. The mind draws afflictions, afflictions draw karma, and karma draws the body.
Because of greed, form and sound become wonderful, and deportment becomes leisurely;
Because of anger, form and sound become coarse and evil, and deportment becomes abrupt.
As with anger, so it is with delusion.
In countless worlds, there are 136 hells, countless animals, and countless hungry ghosts, all created by karma;
Humans and gods are also like this.
Countless beings attain liberation, also due to karma.
Good son!
These ten wholesome deeds have three aspects:
First, they can restrain afflictions; second, they can create wholesome thoughts; third, they can increase precepts.
It is like removing poison, which generally requires three things:
First, agada medicine; second, divine spells; third, genuine treasures.
If a person diligently practices non-negligence, is fully mindful, and distinguishes good from evil, know that such a person will definitely be able to cultivate the ten wholesome courses of action;
If one is often negligent, has no shame or conscience, and lacks faith, know that such a person will definitely be able to commit the ten unwholesome courses of action.
These ten courses of action also have three aspects:
First, means; second, root; third, completion.

If a person is able to diligently pay homage and make offerings to parents, teachers, preceptors, and virtuous people, to greet them with a sincere mind, and to speak with gentle words, this is called means;
If, after completing an action, one is able to cultivate mindfulness, rejoice, and not regret it, this is called completion;
If one is fully engaged in the action, this is called the root.
Good sons!
These ten courses of action are also of three kinds: superior, middling, and inferior.ğŸ”½Sometimes the means are superior, the fundamental is middling, and the completion is inferior;
sometimes the means are middling, the fundamental is superior, and the completion is inferior;
sometimes the means are inferior, the fundamental is superior, and the completion is middling.
These ten courses of action are surrounded by three dharmas, namely non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion, and greed, hatred, and delusion.
These ten courses of action have both shared precepts and unshared precepts.
There are six ways of abandoning the precepts:

First, when severing the roots of goodness; second, when obtaining the two faculties; third, when giving up one's life; fourth, when receiving evil precepts; fifth, when abandoning the precepts; sixth, when abandoning the body of the desire realm.
Some also say that when the Buddha's teachings are extinguished, the precepts are lost, but this is not so!
Why is it so?
Having received it, one does not lose it. One cannot receive it without receiving it.
Cutting off evil of body, speech, and mind is called the precepts of the precepts;ğŸ”½The four fundamental dhyanas and the four preliminary dhyanas are called the precepts of concentration;
The four fundamental dhyanas and the preliminary dhyana of the first dhyana are called the precepts of the undefiled.
Abandoning the body in the next life and never doing evil again is called the precepts of non-action.

Guarding the faculties, cultivating right mindfulness, seeing, hearing, knowing, form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas without giving rise to heedlessness is called the precepts of guarding the faculties.
For what reasons are they called precepts?
Precepts are called restraints, able to restrain all unwholesome dharmas, thus they are called restraints.
Moreover, precepts are called narrow, although there are evil dharmas, their nature cannot accommodate them, thus they are called narrow.
Moreover, precepts are called cool, blocking the heat of afflictions and not allowing them to enter, thus they are called cool.
Moreover, precepts are called superior because they can ascend to heaven and reach the unsurpassed path, therefore they are called superior.
Moreover, precepts are called learning, learning to tame the mind, wisdom, and the faculties, therefore they are called learning.
Good son!
Sometimes there are people who possess one precept, namely the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts;
Some possess two precepts, adding the precepts of concentration;
Some possess three precepts, adding the precepts without outflows;
Some possess four precepts, adding the precepts of guarding the faculties;
Some possess five precepts, adding the precepts without action.
Good son!
The prÄtimoká¹£a precepts are obtained in the present, while the precepts of concentration are obtained in the three times.
Good son!

If there are people who wish to receive the precepts, if they can wholeheartedly contemplate the faults of saá¹ƒsÄra and the merits of liberation, and if their faith and joy are sincere, then these people will also obtain the precepts of action and non-action.

Such precepts are obtained for as long as one's life span, whether long or short. If the life span is long, they are obtained for a long time; if the life span is short, they are obtained for a short time.
These unconditioned precepts are abandoned due to three causes:
First, because of insufficient adornment; second, because of letting go of the mind; third, because of not making them firm.
There are also three causes for not abandoning them:
First, because of having a fundamental vow; second, because of making the practice firm; third, because of being diligent with utmost sincerity.
Good man!

Apart from the ten wholesome and unwholesome actions, the precepts and prohibitions, there are other dharmas that are neither included in actions nor precepts, namely, the wholesome and unwholesome dharmas.

Thus, the wholesome and unwholesome have conditioned and unconditioned aspects. Some people fully possess both the conditioned and unconditioned aspects. If one is currently engaging in wholesome actions and has not yet abandoned them, one possesses both the conditioned and unconditioned aspects;
in the second moment, one accomplishes the past conditioned and unconditioned aspects;
after the action is completed and past, there is only the unconditioned aspect, not the conditioned aspect.
If a person obtains precepts and although they do evil, in this present life they accomplish two dharmas:
Evil dharmas have action, and good dharmas have no action.
These actions and non-actions are abandoned due to two causes:
First, when the given objects are exhausted, second, when the mind abandons goodness.
Actions are accomplished in two time periods - past and present - while non-actions are in the three time periods.
The precepts of concentration are abandoned due to two causes:
First, when regressing, second, when severing wholesome roots.
There are also three time periods:
First, when abandoning the body, second, when regressing, third, when being born in a higher realm.
Impermanent precepts are abandoned at three times:
First, when regressing, second, when turning dull and becoming sharp, third, when attaining the upper fruits.
The wholesome mind is lost at one time, namely when being born above and regressing;
The wholesome body, speech, and mind are all lost when severing wholesome roots.
Good sons!
If one attains the precepts of full ordination, the precepts of concentration, the precepts without outflows, and the precepts of guarding the faculties, then one understands the ten paths of action.
Good sons!
Due to the ten paths of action, the lifespans of sentient beings increase and decrease:
Those with decreasing lifespans live for ten years, while those with increasing lifespans live for immeasurable years.
In Uttarakuru, the lifespan is fixed at one thousand years, while here it is one hundred years. In the eastern and western continents, it is two hundred and fifty years.
Here the lifespan is immeasurable, and there it is also immeasurable.
The lifespan of the Four Heavenly Kings is nine million years, and their lives are also indefinite, like in the three lower heavens.
The lifespan of the Thirty-three Celestials is eighteen million years, and their lives are also indefinite.
The lifespan in the YÄma Heaven is thirty-six million years, and their lives are also indefinite.
The lifespan in the Tuá¹£ita Heaven is seventy-two million years, except for bodhisattvas in their last life, the lives of all others are also indefinite.
The lifespan of the Heaven of Delight in Emanations is 14,400,400 years, but it is also not fixed.
The lifespan of the Heaven of Freely Partaking of the Pleasures Created in Other Heavens is 28,800,800 years, but it is also not fixed.
One year in the Heaven of Freely Partaking of the Pleasures Created in Other Heavens is one day and night in the Hot Hell;
thirty such days are one month, and twelve such months are one year. The lifespan in that hell is 28,800,800 years, but it is also not fixed.
One year in the Heaven of Delight in Emanations is one day and night in the Great Sound Hell;
thirty such days are one month, and twelve such months are one year. The lifespan in that hell is 14,400,400 years, but it is also not fixed.
One year in the Heaven of Satisfaction is one day and night in the Small Sound Hell;
thirty such days are one month, and twelve such months are one year. The lifespan in that hell is 7,200,000 years, but it is also not fixed.
One year in the Heaven of YÄma is one day and night in the Saá¹ƒghÄta Hell;
Thirty such days are one month, and twelve such months are one year. The lifespan in that hell is 3.6 million years, and life is also indefinite.
Thirty years in the Heaven of the Thirty-three is one day and night in the Raurava Hell;
Thirty such days are one month, and twelve such months are one year. The lifespan in that hell is 18 million years, and life is also indefinite.
One year in the Heaven of the Four Kings is one day and night in the Saá¹ƒjÄ«va Hell;
Thirty such days are one month, and twelve such months are one year. The lifespan in that hell is 9 million years, and life is also indefinite.
The lifespan in the AvÄ«ci Hell is one eon, and the lifespan in the Tapana Hell is half an eon. Only in these two places is the lifespan definite.
Five hundred years in the human realm is one day and night in the realm of hungry ghosts;
Thirty such days make one month, and twelve months make one year. The lifespan of such ghosts is fifteen thousand years, but it is also uncertain.
In the animal realm, except for Nanda and Upananda, the lifespans of all other animals are also uncertain.
One year in AvÄ«ci Hell is one day and night in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
Thirty such days make one month, and twelve months make one year. The lifespan of the gods there is eighty thousand great eons;
in the base of nothingness, sixty thousand eons; in the base of consciousness, forty thousand eons; and in the base of infinite space, twenty thousand eons.
If one gives rise to slight afflictions and becomes attached to the concentration on emptiness, one should know that this person will be reborn in the four formless [realms].
From ten years increasing to eighty thousand years, and from eighty thousand years decreasing back to ten years, this increase and decrease is completed eighteen times, called an intermediate eon.
The three calamities of famine, the three calamities of disease, and the one calamity of warfare are called a small eon.
After the two calamities of water and fire each pass through five stages, there is one wind calamity. After five wind calamities, it is called a great eon.

When warfare arises in JambudvÄ«pa, the people in the east and west temporarily give rise to anger. When this disease arises, they have a slight headache and little strength. When there is famine here, they think of food there. Such evil things do not exist in Uttarakuru.
Because of not killing, life spans increase;
because of stealing, life spans decrease.
There are two kinds of eons:
the water eon and the fire eon.
When the fire eon arises, if the beings in the hells have finished their karmic retribution, they all escape, but if it is not finished, they are moved to the great hells in other worlds.
If the eight great hells in this world are empty and without beings, this is called beings escaping the hells.
All the beings in the four great oceans, if their karma is exhausted, will all be liberated;
If it is not exhausted, they will all be reborn in other oceans.
If there is not a single being in this ocean, it is called liberation.
Five hundred yojanas straight below the ground of JambudvÄ«pa, there is the city of King Yama, seven and fifty thousand yojanas in circumference.
In such a city, hungry ghosts whose karma is exhausted will all be able to escape;
Those whose karma is not exhausted will be reborn in other places under King Yama.
If there is not a single being in this city, it is called liberation.

At that time, there was a person who, due to internal causes and conditions, attained the first dhyÄna. Having attained it, he immediately arose and shouted loudly, saying:ğŸ”½The first dhyÄna is tranquil!
The first dhyÄna is tranquil!
Upon hearing this, all the people each contemplated and attained the first dhyÄna together. They then abandoned their human bodies and were reborn in the first dhyÄna heaven.

The second dhyÄna is tranquil!
Upon hearing this, the sentient beings each contemplated and again attained the second dhyÄna. They abandoned their first dhyÄna bodies and were reborn in the second dhyÄna heaven.

Outside the four continents, there is Mount Yugandhara, in which there are seven suns. Due to the power of the causes and conditions of sentient beings' blessings and virtues, only one sun appears, relying on it to ripen the hundred grains, grasses, and trees.
When the fire kalpa arises, the seven suns appear together, burning all the hundred grains, grasses and trees, mountains, rivers, earth, Mount Sumeru, and even the first dhyana heaven.
The beings in the second dhyana heaven see this fire disaster and are frightened. There are also gods born there earlier who tell the later gods:
You should not be afraid!
I have seen such a fire disaster before, and it stopped there, not coming here.

As the lifespan of beings increases from ten years to eighty thousand years, and decreases from eighty thousand years back to ten years, after that period of time, the heat of the fire disaster has not yet subsided.

At that time, it rains heavily from the intermediate dhyana heaven. After another increase and decrease in lifespan, due to the power of the karmic actions of beings, in order to hold this water, seven layers of wind and clouds appear below again.
At that time, when the rain stops, a film forms on the water, like the cream on milk.
In the four continents, Mount Sumeru gradually appears, and in the water, all kinds of seeds naturally appear.

At that time, in the second meditation heaven, there was a person with a short lifespan whose blessings were exhausted. Due to the power of karma, he fell and was born in the world, with a lifespan of countless years, illuminating himself with his own light. Living alone for a long time, he became sorrowful and thought to himself:
Since I am alone, if I have blessings, I wish that more people will come and be born here to be my companions.

After thinking this, at that time, in the second meditation heaven, there were sentient beings whose blessings were thin and whose lifespans were exhausted. Due to the causes and conditions of karma, they came and were born here.
When this person saw them, he was overjoyed and thought to himself:
These people were transformed and born by me. They were created by me. I have sovereign power over those people.
Those people also thought:
We were born from him. He transformed and created us. He has sovereign power over our bodies.
